title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 15.

questions.question: What is the gospel that Paul preached according to 1 Corinthians 15:3?
options: Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures
Christ built a temple for us
Christ performed many miracles
Christ wrote scriptures
questions.correctAnswer: Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:3 states that Paul delivered that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15:4, when did Christ rise again?
options: The third day
The seventh day
The first day
The tenth day
questions.correctAnswer: The third day
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:4 mentions that Christ rose again the third day according to the scriptures.

questions.question: Who was the first person Jesus was seen by after His resurrection, as mentioned in 1 Corinthians 15:5?
options: Cephas
James
Paul
The twelve
questions.correctAnswer: Cephas
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:5 states that Jesus was seen of Cephas first, then of the twelve.

questions.question: How many brethren saw Christ at once after His resurrection according to 1 Corinthians 15:6?
options: More than five hundred
One hundred
Fifty
Two hundred
questions.correctAnswer: More than five hundred
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:6 says Christ was seen by above five hundred brethren at once.

questions.question: Who saw Christ last of all, as mentioned in 1 Corinthians 15:8?
options: Paul
Peter
James
John
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:8 states that last of all Christ was seen by Paul, described as born out of due time.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 15:12, some among the Corinthians denied the resurrection of the dead.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:12 mentions some among the Corinthians saying there is no resurrection of the dead.

questions.question: If there is no resurrection of the dead, what does 1 Corinthians 15:14 say about our faith?
options: Our faith is vain
Our faith is strong
Our faith is justified
Our faith is rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: Our faith is vain
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:14 explains that if Christ is not risen, then our preaching and faith are vain.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15:20, Christ is described as what in relation to those who have died?
options: The firstfruits of them that slept
The teacher of the lost
The shepherd of the flock
The judge of the living
questions.correctAnswer: The firstfruits of them that slept
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:20 says Christ has risen and become the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15:22, in whom shall all be made alive?
options: Christ
Adam
Noah
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:22 declares that as in Adam all die, so in Christ shall all be made alive.

questions.question: What is the last enemy to be destroyed according to 1 Corinthians 15:26?
options: Death
Sin
Satan
Pride
questions.correctAnswer: Death
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:26 clearly states that the last enemy that shall be destroyed is death.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 15:33 warns that evil communications corrupt good manners.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:33 warns believers not to be deceived because evil communications corrupt good manners.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15:42, how is the resurrection of the dead described?
options: Sown in corruption; raised in incorruption
Sown in glory; raised in weakness
Sown in power; raised in dishonour
Sown in spirit; raised in flesh
questions.correctAnswer: Sown in corruption; raised in incorruption
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:42 describes the resurrection as sown in corruption and raised in incorruption.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 1 Corinthians 15:44 says, 'It is sown a ______ body; it is raised a spiritual body.'
options: natural
corruptible
glorious
immortal
questions.correctAnswer: natural
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:44 states that it is sown a natural body and raised a spiritual body.

questions.question: Who is called the 'last Adam' in 1 Corinthians 15:45?
options: The Lord Jesus Christ
Paul
Cephas
James
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:45 calls the last Adam a quickening spirit, referring to Jesus Christ.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 15:50, flesh and blood can inherit the kingdom of God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:50 says flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God.

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel their efforts in serving God are unnoticed. Based on 1 Corinthians 15, what truth would encourage them to persevere?
options: Their labor is not in vain in the Lord.
They must work harder to be accepted by God.
Only apostles have meaningful service.
God only values public ministry.
questions.correctAnswer: Their labor is not in vain in the Lord.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:58 encourages believers to be steadfast and unmovable in their work for the Lord because their labor is not in vain. This assures us that God values faithful service, even when unseen.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 15 teach us about faith and trust in God when facing doubts about resurrection?
options: If Christ did not rise, our faith is vain.
Doubting resurrection is acceptable.
Faith is independent of resurrection.
Resurrection is a minor doctrine.
questions.correctAnswer: If Christ did not rise, our faith is vain.
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 emphasize that if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not risen and our faith is in vain. This teaches the centrality of resurrection to Christian faith and trust in God's power.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with temptation and sin. According to 1 Corinthians 15, what hope can you share about victory over sin and death?
options: Victory comes through Jesus Christ.
We must overcome sin by our own strength.
Death has ultimate power over us.
Sin is unavoidable and permanent.
questions.correctAnswer: Victory comes through Jesus Christ.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:57 teaches that God gives us victory through our Lord Jesus Christ, reminding believers that through Him we overcome the sting of death and sin.

questions.question: In what way does 1 Corinthians 15 model humility for believers in their service and identity?
options: Paul calls himself the least of the apostles because he persecuted the church.
Believers should boast in their accomplishments.
Only apostles are worthy of respect.
Humility is not necessary in Christian service.
questions.correctAnswer: Paul calls himself the least of the apostles because he persecuted the church.
questions.explanation: In verses 9-10, Paul humbly acknowledges his past and unworthiness but credits God's grace for his ministry, teaching believers to be humble and dependent on God's grace.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 15 teach about perseverance through trials and daily struggles?
options: Paul says he dies daily for Christ, showing commitment despite hardship.
Believers should avoid difficulties at all costs.
Suffering means God has abandoned you.
Trials disqualify believers from reward.
questions.correctAnswer: Paul says he dies daily for Christ, showing commitment despite hardship.
questions.explanation: Verse 31 shows Paul’s daily commitment and willingness to face jeopardy for Christ, encouraging believers to persevere through trials with steadfastness.

questions.question: What biblical principle about spiritual transformation is taught in 1 Corinthians 15 regarding our resurrection bodies?
options: We shall bear the image of the heavenly, not just the earthly.
Our resurrection bodies will be identical to our earthly bodies.
There is no difference between natural and spiritual bodies.
Our physical bodies will remain corruptible.
questions.correctAnswer: We shall bear the image of the heavenly, not just the earthly.
questions.explanation: Verses 49 and 44 explain the difference between natural and spiritual bodies and that believers will bear the image of the heavenly, showing transformation beyond our earthly state.

questions.question: Based on 1 Corinthians 15, what is the significance of Christ being the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep?
options: Christ’s resurrection guarantees the resurrection of believers.
Christ was the only one resurrected.
Resurrection is symbolic only.
Only a few will be resurrected.
questions.correctAnswer: Christ’s resurrection guarantees the resurrection of believers.
questions.explanation: Verse 20 states that Christ is the firstfruits of those who have died, implying that believers will also be raised, giving hope and assurance in resurrection.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 15 counsel believers regarding the influence of bad company on spiritual life?
options: Bad company corrupts good manners.
Company has no effect on spiritual life.
Believers should not worry about friends.
Evil company strengthens faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Bad company corrupts good manners.
questions.explanation: Verse 33 warns believers not to be deceived because evil communications corrupt good manners, emphasizing the importance of godly fellowship for spiritual integrity.

questions.question: A believer doubts the reality of the resurrection of the dead. According to 1 Corinthians 15, what biblical truth can you share?
options: If there is no resurrection, then Christ has not risen.
Resurrection is a myth.
Faith does not depend on resurrection.
The dead remain in the grave forever.
questions.correctAnswer: If there is no resurrection, then Christ has not risen.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 clearly states that without the resurrection of the dead, Christ has not been raised, showing the foundational nature of resurrection for Christian belief.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 15 teach about how believers should respond to the certainty of resurrection in their daily lives?
options: Be steadfast, unmovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord.
Live carelessly since resurrection is future.
Ignore service to others.
Focus only on earthly pleasures.
questions.correctAnswer: Be steadfast, unmovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord.
questions.explanation: Verse 58 calls believers to steadfastness and abundant labor in the Lord’s work, motivated by the certainty of resurrection and reward.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 15, the last enemy that will be destroyed is sin.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 26 states that the last enemy to be destroyed is death, not sin. This shows the ultimate victory over death at the end of time.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 15 teaches that flesh and blood can inherit the kingdom of God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 50 states that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, emphasizing the need for transformation into incorruption to enter heaven.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 1 Corinthians 15:54 says, "So when this corruptible shall have put on _______, and this mortal shall have put on immortality, then shall be brought to pass the saying that is written, Death is swallowed up in victory."
options: incorruption
weakness
sin
death
questions.correctAnswer: incorruption
questions.explanation: Verse 54 explains the transformation from corruptible to incorruption, which brings about victory over death, signifying the resurrection's power.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 15 instruct believers to maintain integrity and steadfastness in evangelism and witnessing?
options: Preach consistently that Christ rose from the dead.
Change the gospel to suit audiences.
Avoid preaching about resurrection.
Only apostles should preach.
questions.correctAnswer: Preach consistently that Christ rose from the dead.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 shows Paul affirming that whether he or others preach, the message is the same: Christ rose from the dead, and believers should hold firmly to this truth in their witness.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the fear of death. Based on 1 Corinthians 15, what biblical encouragement can you share about death's sting?
options: Death’s sting is sin, but thanks be to God who gives victory through Jesus Christ.
Death is the end with no hope.
Sin has no power over death.
Death cannot be defeated.
questions.correctAnswer: Death’s sting is sin, but thanks be to God who gives victory through Jesus Christ.
questions.explanation: Verses 55-57 explain that the sting of death is sin, but believers have victory through Jesus Christ, providing hope over fear of death.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15, what is the foundational event that the gospel Paul preached is based upon?
options: The resurrection of Christ on the third day
The baptism of believers
The establishment of the church in Corinth
The destruction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection of Christ on the third day
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:3-4 clearly states that Christ died for our sins, was buried, and rose again on the third day according to the scriptures, which is the gospel Paul preached.

questions.question: What does Paul emphasize as the proof of Christ's resurrection in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: Christ was seen by Cephas, the twelve, over 500 brethren, James, all apostles, and lastly Paul himself
The fulfillment of Old Testament prophecies only
The destruction of death itself
The conversion of the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Christ was seen by Cephas, the twelve, over 500 brethren, James, all apostles, and lastly Paul himself
questions.explanation: Paul lists eyewitnesses to Christ's resurrection to validate its historicity and reality, as seen in 1 Corinthians 15:5-8.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 15, how does Paul describe his own status among the apostles?
options: The least of the apostles, unworthy to be called an apostle because he persecuted the church
The chief apostle with highest authority
A prophet but not an apostle
A disciple chosen at the same time as the twelve
questions.correctAnswer: The least of the apostles, unworthy to be called an apostle because he persecuted the church
questions.explanation: Paul humbly refers to himself as the least of the apostles because of his past persecution, according to 1 Corinthians 15:9.

questions.question: True or False: Paul argues that if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not been raised.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 15:13 and 16, Paul explicitly connects the resurrection of the dead with Christ's resurrection, stating that if the dead do not rise, Christ is not raised.

questions.question: What consequence does Paul assert if Christ has not been raised, according to 1 Corinthians 15?
options: Our preaching and faith are vain, and we remain in our sins
The church will expand rapidly
All believers will be physically immortal
The law will become obsolete
questions.correctAnswer: Our preaching and faith are vain, and we remain in our sins
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 1 Corinthians 15:14 and 17 that without Christ's resurrection, preaching and faith are meaningless, and believers remain in sin.

questions.question: What does Paul call death in 1 Corinthians 15:26, and what significance does it hold in the chapter's theology?
options: The last enemy to be destroyed, signifying the ultimate defeat through resurrection
A punishment for the Gentiles
A temporary state before reincarnation
A symbol of evil powers ruling the world
questions.correctAnswer: The last enemy to be destroyed, signifying the ultimate defeat through resurrection
questions.explanation: Verse 26 identifies death as the final enemy to be overcome through Christ's resurrection, highlighting victory over death as a core theme.

questions.question: How does Paul use the agricultural metaphor in 1 Corinthians 15 to explain the resurrection body?
options: He compares the resurrection body to a seed sown which is transformed into a new body by God
He equates the resurrection to a harvest festival celebrating abundance
He likens resurrection to the planting of a vineyard
He uses the metaphor of a tree growing from a stump
questions.correctAnswer: He compares the resurrection body to a seed sown which is transformed into a new body by God
questions.explanation: Verses 35-38 use the analogy of sowing a seed which dies and is transformed into a new body, illustrating the transformation in resurrection.

questions.question: What distinction does Paul make between 'natural' and 'spiritual' bodies in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: The natural body is perishable and mortal; the spiritual body is imperishable and immortal
The natural body is more important than the spiritual body
The spiritual body is temporary, while the natural body is eternal
Both bodies are identical in every way
questions.correctAnswer: The natural body is perishable and mortal; the spiritual body is imperishable and immortal
questions.explanation: Verses 42-44 explain that the resurrection body differs fundamentally from the earthly body, being raised incorruptible and spiritual.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15, who is the 'firstfruits' of those who have fallen asleep?
options: Christ, as the first to rise from the dead
Adam, as the first man
Moses, as the leader of Israel
Noah, as the survivor of the flood
questions.correctAnswer: Christ, as the first to rise from the dead
questions.explanation: Verse 20 describes Christ as the firstfruits of those who have died, indicating he is the first to be resurrected to eternal life.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 15:22, Paul makes a comparison between Adam and Christ. What is the theological significance of this comparison?
options: Through Adam all die, but through Christ all will be made alive, showing typology of death and resurrection
Adam and Christ are identical figures
Adam's sin is irrelevant to salvation
Christ replaces the law given to Adam
questions.correctAnswer: Through Adam all die, but through Christ all will be made alive, showing typology of death and resurrection
questions.explanation: Paul uses Adam as a type whose sin brought death to all, while Christ brings life, illustrating deep theological typology and redemption.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by stating 'flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God' in 1 Corinthians 15:50?
options: Corruptible human nature cannot inherit eternal life without transformation
Only animals can inherit the kingdom
The physical body is immortal as is
Material wealth determines inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: Corruptible human nature cannot inherit eternal life without transformation
questions.explanation: This emphasizes that the mortal, perishable body cannot enter God's kingdom without the resurrection transformation to an incorruptible body.

questions.question: What is the 'mystery' Paul reveals in 1 Corinthians 15:51, and how does it relate to the resurrection?
options: Not all will die ('sleep'), but all will be changed at the last trumpet
The mystery of the Trinity
The secret of the law of Moses
The hidden wisdom of the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Not all will die ('sleep'), but all will be changed at the last trumpet
questions.explanation: Paul reveals that some believers will be transformed without dying, highlighting the eschatological change at Christ’s return.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 15:54-55 use Old Testament scripture to describe the victory over death?
options: It quotes Isaiah 25:8 and Hosea 13:14 to proclaim death swallowed up and its sting taken away
It references Psalm 23 about the shepherd
It cites Genesis about creation
It paraphrases Exodus about the Passover
questions.correctAnswer: It quotes Isaiah 25:8 and Hosea 13:14 to proclaim death swallowed up and its sting taken away
questions.explanation: Paul uses Old Testament allusions to affirm the ultimate victory over death through resurrection, fulfilling prophetic hope.

questions.question: What exhortation does Paul give to the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 15:58 based on the truths about resurrection?
options: Be steadfast, immovable, and always abounding in the work of the Lord because labor is not in vain
Avoid all suffering and persecution
Focus only on earthly pleasures
Separate from the community of believers
questions.correctAnswer: Be steadfast, immovable, and always abounding in the work of the Lord because labor is not in vain
questions.explanation: Paul encourages perseverance in service, knowing resurrection guarantees that labor for the Lord is meaningful.

questions.question: Why does Paul mention baptism for the dead in 1 Corinthians 15:29, and what rhetorical purpose does it serve?
options: To argue logically that resurrection must be true, otherwise such practices are meaningless
To promote a new sacrament
To criticize pagan rituals
To describe a historical event
questions.correctAnswer: To argue logically that resurrection must be true, otherwise such practices are meaningless
questions.explanation: Paul uses this practice, known to some Corinthians, as a rhetorical argument proving the reality of resurrection.

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15, what is the foundational truth of the gospel Paul preached?
options: Christ died for our sins, was buried, and rose again the third day
Faith alone without works saves
The law of Moses must be perfectly kept
Angels delivered God's final message
questions.correctAnswer: Christ died for our sins, was buried, and rose again the third day
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:3-4 states that the gospel Paul preached is that Christ died for our sins, was buried, and rose again on the third day, fulfilling the scriptures. This foundational gospel truth is also affirmed in Romans 4:25, Romans 6:4, Isaiah 53:5, and Luke 24:7.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 15, who does Paul claim was the last to see the risen Christ?
options: Paul himself
James
Cephas (Peter)
The twelve apostles
questions.correctAnswer: Paul himself
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states that Paul was the last to see the risen Christ, describing himself as one born out of due time. This unique apostolic experience is also noted in Acts 9:3-6, Galatians 1:15-16, Luke 24:39, and John 20:19-29.

questions.question: What consequence does Paul outline if there is no resurrection of the dead?
options: Christ is not risen, and our faith is vain
The law is abolished
Sin no longer has power
Salvation is guaranteed by works
questions.correctAnswer: Christ is not risen, and our faith is vain
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 explain that without the resurrection of the dead, Christ has not been raised, making preaching and faith useless. This truth is supported by Romans 4:25, Acts 2:24, 1 Peter 1:3, and John 11:25.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 15, what is described as the 'last enemy' to be destroyed?
options: Death
Sin
Satan
The Law
questions.correctAnswer: Death
questions.explanation: Verse 26 clearly states that death is the last enemy to be destroyed. This aligns with Revelation 20:14, Hebrews 2:14, Romans 6:23, and Isaiah 25:8 where death’s final defeat is foretold.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the nature of the resurrection body compared to the earthly body?
options: The resurrection body is spiritual and incorruptible
The resurrection body is identical to the earthly body
The resurrection body is less glorious
The resurrection body is temporary
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection body is spiritual and incorruptible
questions.explanation: Verses 42-44 teach that the resurrection body is raised imperishable, glorious, powerful, and spiritual, unlike the natural earthly body. This concept is consistent with Philippians 3:21, John 3:6, 2 Corinthians 5:1-4, and Daniel 12:2.

questions.question: According to Paul in 1 Corinthians 15, who will be made alive in Christ?
options: All who are in Christ, as all die in Adam
Only the apostles
Only those who keep the law perfectly
Only the righteous of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: All who are in Christ, as all die in Adam
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states that just as all die in Adam, so all will be made alive in Christ. This universal scope of resurrection is echoed in Romans 5:12-21, Genesis 3:19, Ezekiel 37:12-14, and John 5:28-29.

questions.question: What mystery does Paul reveal in 1 Corinthians 15 about believers and death?
options: Not all believers will die, but all will be changed
All believers must die before resurrection
Only those baptized will be resurrected
Death has no power over believers
questions.correctAnswer: Not all believers will die, but all will be changed
questions.explanation: Verse 51 reveals the mystery that not all will sleep (die), but all will be changed, signifying transformation at Christ’s return. This aligns with John 11:25-26, Isaiah 26:19, 1 Thessalonians 4:16-17, and Revelation 21:4.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 15, what is the significance of Christ being called the 'firstfruits' of those who have fallen asleep?
options: He is the first to rise and the guarantee of believers’ resurrection
He was the only one resurrected
He is the last to be resurrected
He resurrected by his own power alone
questions.correctAnswer: He is the first to rise and the guarantee of believers’ resurrection
questions.explanation: Verse 20 calls Christ the firstfruits, indicating He rose first and is the first of many to come. This agricultural metaphor is consistent with Romans 8:23, James 1:18, and John 14:19.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the origin of death and resurrection in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: Death came through man, and resurrection also through man
Death and resurrection are unrelated events
Resurrection comes only through angels
Death is eternal with no resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: Death came through man, and resurrection also through man
questions.explanation: Verse 21 teaches that death entered the world through man (Adam), and likewise resurrection is through man (Christ). This is supported by Genesis 3:19, Romans 5:12, Hebrews 2:14, and John 1:14.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 15, what happens when 'all things shall be subdued unto him'?
options: Then the Son shall be subject to God the Father
Then the Son will reign forever independently
Then the angels will rule over the earth
Then the kingdom will end
questions.correctAnswer: Then the Son shall be subject to God the Father
questions.explanation: Verse 28 explains that after all things are subjected to the Son, He will subject Himself to God the Father so that God may be all in all. This reflects the eternal order and unity in the Godhead, as seen also in John 14:28, Philippians 2:9-11, Ephesians 1:22, and Hebrews 1:3.

questions.question: What is the role of grace in Paul's apostleship as described in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: Grace made Paul what he is and enabled his abundant labor
Grace was unimportant compared to his own efforts
Grace was only for the original twelve apostles
Grace was given only after Paul's death
questions.correctAnswer: Grace made Paul what he is and enabled his abundant labor
questions.explanation: Verse 10 reveals that by God’s grace Paul became who he is and labored more abundantly than others, but it was God’s grace with him, not his own strength. This is consistent with Ephesians 2:8-9, 1 Timothy 1:14, 2 Corinthians 12:9, and Romans 15:15.

questions.question: How does Paul address the practice of 'baptism for the dead' in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: It is used as evidence for resurrection of the dead
It is condemned as heresy
It guarantees salvation for the dead
It is a public confession of sin
questions.correctAnswer: It is used as evidence for resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Verse 29 questions what those baptized for the dead would do if there is no resurrection, implying the practice assumes resurrection is true. This reflects the early church’s belief in resurrection, as supported by Acts 2:31, Luke 20:38, Hebrews 11:35, and John 5:28.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the relationship between sin, death, and the law in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: The sting of death is sin, and the strength of sin is the law
The law overcomes sin and death
Sin and death have no relation to the law
The law is stronger than sin
questions.correctAnswer: The sting of death is sin, and the strength of sin is the law
questions.explanation: Verse 56 states that sin gives death its sting, and the law gives sin its strength. This theological insight is supported by Romans 7:7-13, James 2:10, Genesis 2:17, and Romans 6:23.

questions.question: What exhortation does Paul give to believers at the end of 1 Corinthians 15?
options: Be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord
Avoid all suffering and persecution
Follow the law perfectly to be saved
Withdraw from the world
questions.correctAnswer: Be steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the work of the Lord
questions.explanation: Verse 58 exhorts believers to remain steadfast and immovable, always abounding in the Lord’s work because their labor is not in vain. This encouragement is echoed in James 1:12, Hebrews 12:1-2, Galatians 6:9, and Romans 12:11.

questions.question: What analogy does Paul use to explain the transformation of the resurrection body?
options: The seed that is sown dies to bring forth a new body
A potter shaping clay into a vessel
A shepherd leading sheep to pasture
A lamp lighting a dark room
questions.correctAnswer: The seed that is sown dies to bring forth a new body
questions.explanation: Verses 36-38 compare the resurrection body to a seed sown into the ground that must die to bring forth a new body, showing God’s sovereign power in creating new life. Supporting texts include John 12:24, Isaiah 53:10, Ezekiel 37:5-6, and Romans 8:11.
